head.title: Its Time to Call Out the Fiberglass Posse

hedline.hl1: Its Time to Call Out the Fiberglass Posse

block.p: ON Monday morning, Moo-Stripa, a seven-foot-long fiberglass cow that is part of the 500 such statues that make up a citywide art event called Cow Parade 2000, stood contentedly in Forest Park in Richmond Hill, Queens.

ON Monday morning, Moo-Stripa, a seven-foot-long fiberglass cow that is part of the 500 such statues that make up a citywide art event called Cow Parade 2000, stood contentedly in Forest Park in Richmond Hill, Queens.
Sometime after 11 a.m., she disappeared, the police said. Since the cow was bolted to a 500-pound concrete base, foul play is suspected.
Moo-Stripa, who was decorated by a seventh-grade student at P.S. 43 in Queens, has orange, white, green and blue stripes. She is four feet tall and weighs 80 pounds.
Pat Smith, a spokesman for Cow Parade 2000, said that some vandalism had been expected, and that half of a dozen cows had had ears cut off or flanks defaced with graffiti.
Nevertheless, the sponsors of the exhibition, Cow Parade Holdings Corporation, have offered a $1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the cow thief.

The corporation's president, Jerome Elbaum, had a question: ''Why would anyone want to damage these beautiful cows, which were decorated with such love and creativity by talented artists, including New York City schoolchildren?''
